awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Phylanx: Python based Array Processing in HPX
awd_abstract_narration:
The availability and size of data sets has increased significantly over the course of the past decade. To enable the analysis of large data sets on High Performance Computing (HPC) resources while minimizing time- and energy-to-solution requires incorporating static and runtime information to determine the best possible data layout of the large data arrays used by an application to minimize data movement. The goal of this proposal is to deliver Phylanx, a general purpose framework supporting a variety of data science, machine learning, and statistically oriented applications. Phylanx is designed such that a user?s code will be able to perform efficiently on current and future architecture as long as the runtime system is maintained. This greatly reduces the maintenance burden and will increase the productivity of domain scientists. Phylanx lays a solid foundation for technology transfer from academia to industry and fills the gap between academic innovation and commercial application, by creating a software layer that industrial partners can feel confident relying upon. 
Phylanx is a scalable, array-based and distributed framework targeting HPC systems using the HPX, dynamic asynchronous task-based parallel runtime system. The dataflow-style capabilities exposed by HPX guarantee the preservation of all data-dependencies even for complex distributed workflows. This project overcomes some of the limitations of existing Big Data solutions such as Hadoop, Spark, and Flink by providing users the ability to: implement NumPy-styled expression-graphs using Python or C/C++, optimize these graphs for optimal data layout, distribution, tiling, and minimal communication overheads, and evaluate those graphs with high efficiency on a runtime interpreter targeting distributed HPC systems. Additionally, Phylanx uses greedy sub-modular techniques on the expression tree to provide a mathematically provable guarantee of optimal performance in machine learning domains and in data placement problems. The platform will provide implementations of 6 benchmarks which have been selected for their domain specificity in text, image, and graph applications.

por.por_cntn:
The availability and size of data sets has increased significantly over the course of the past decade. Several technologies have been developed specifically to enable the analysis of large data sets. In the past few years, the fields of artificial intelligence and data mining have evolved into additional highly-publicized areas such as machine learning and deep learning.  User-friendly scientific software capable of performing these analyses have evolved with the fields, however, data sets have grown to such an extent that large-scale high performance computing (HPC) resources are needed to process all the data in a timely fashion. Nevertheless, these platforms lack the high-level programming interfaces with which data scientists are familiar.

Phylanx is an array-based and distributed framework (targeted to HPC systems using the HPX runtime) that overcomes some of the limitations of existing systems such as Hadoop, Spark, and Flink.  HPX (High Performance ParalleX) is a general purpose C++ runtime system for parallel and distributed applications of any scale.  The developed framework produced by the Phylanx project provides users the ability to implement NumPy-styled expression-graphs using Python or C/C++.  The platform provides implementations of benchmarks which have been selected for their domain specificity in text, image, and graph applications.  The benchmarks implemented so far include Logistical Regression (LRA), Alternating Least Squares (ALS) and K-Means clustering, along with a linear solver and LU Decomposition. These algorithms are composed from primitive operations implemented in HPX. All software is freely available in public repositories.

The goals of the Phylanx research project are to: (1) enable best possible performance capabilities for array-based big-data applications, both current and future, (2) develop and deliver a practical computing framework, for future practical big-data analysis, and (3) provide programming methods, environments, and tools for effective means of expressing array-based big-data applications for portable HPC system execution.

Modified by: Kevin Huck
